vague_description: The issue at hand involves optimizing the production of two medicines within resource constraints to maximize patient treatment.
detailed_description: A university research lab can make two types of diabetes medicine, medicine A and medicine B. Per dose, medicine A takes \param{MaterialA} units of imported material and \param{MrnaA} units of mRNA to make. Per dose, medicine B takes \param{MaterialB} units of imported material and \param{MrnaB} units of mRNA to take. The lab has available at most \param{TotalMaterial} units of imported material and \param{TotalMrna} units of mRNA. The lab can make at most \param{MaxDosesA} doses of medicine A and the number of doses of medicine B must be larger than the number of doses of medicine A. If one dose of medicine A can treat \param{PeopleA} people and one dose of medicine B can treat \param{PeopleB} people, how many doses of each should be made to maximize the number of people that can be treated?
target_objective: Maximize the total number of people treated with doses of medicine A and B
target_constraints: Number of doses of medicine A is non-negative
Number of doses of medicine B is non-negative
The lab has at most TotalMaterial units of imported material available
The lab has at most TotalMrna units of mRNA available
The lab can make at most MaxDosesA doses of medicine A
The number of doses of medicine B must be greater than the number of doses of medicine A
target_parameters: Units of imported material to make one dose of medicine A
Units of mRNA to make one dose of medicine A
Units of imported material to make one dose of medicine B
Units of mRNA to make one dose of medicine B
Total units of imported material available
Maximum doses of medicine A that can be made
Number of people treated by one dose of medicine A
Number of people treated by one dose of medicine B
